intro.description: This cheat sheet is a step-by-step description of how to create a models-based requirements specification model. The first installation steps are optional if you already have a so-called RCP version of Papyrus for Requirements.

item.title: Install Papyrus
item.description:
Papyrus is a modeling environment that will be enhanced with extensions for modeling requirements in the next steps.
The easiest way for installing Papyrus is to download it from the Papyrus website. Alternatively, you can install Papyrus in any Eclipse-installation via its update site (listed on the Papyrus Download page). This is recommended for advanced users only who need to integrate Papyrus with other Eclipse-based components.

item.title: Install BMM
item.description: To install the BMM editor go to Help -> Install Papyrus Additional Components. Then, select the BMM in the list of editors.

item.title: Install Metrics
item.description: To install the Metrics extension go to Help -> Install Papyrus Additional Components. Then, select Metrics in the list of tools.

item.title: Install SysML 1.4
item.description: To install the SysML14 editor go to Help -> Install Papyrus Additional Components. Then, select the SysML 1.4 language in the list of editors.

item.title: Install Papyrus for Requirements extension
item.description: To install the SysML14 editor go to the Eclipse Git website dedicated to Papyrus for Requirements to either clone the code or install the plugins using an update site.

item.title: 1. Elicit and Analyze Business Needs
item.description:
Elicitation is to determine the needs of stakeholders from a business perspective.
Elicitation and modeling of business needs are two activities that can be performed iteratively. Elicitation is a synonym of discovering or gathering business needs and is supported by interviews, workshops, documentation reviews, surveys, questionnaires, etc.

item.title: 2. Model Business Needs
item.description:
The Business Motivation Model (BMM) specification is an OMG standard that defines a set of built-in concepts that define the elements of business plans including business needs written in terms of vision, goals and objectives.
The idea is to develop a business model for the elements of the business plans before beginning system design or technical development, or even detailed business modeling. The business plans then become the foundation for such activities, connecting system solutions firmly to their business intent. Some high level constraints and non-functional needs for example, legal and licensing issues or patent-infringement-avoidability, may be included but specified in terms that are understandable and relevant to the business staff. A detailed explanation of BMM can be found in its official webpage (http://www.omg.org/spec/BMM/).

subitem.label: You can skip the following three sub-steps if you have an existing Papyrus project
File >New > Papyrus Project > BMM > Next
Write a name for your project
Check "BMM Diagram" in the field "Select a Diagram Kind"
Click "Browse Registered Profiles" > SysML14 > Finish
Open the BMM diagram and create a vision, goals, objectives, etc using the palette on the right of the diagram.

item.title: 3. Elicit and Analyze Concrete System Requirements
item.description:
The purpose of gathering concrete system requirements is to determine what the system should do.
Elicitation, analysis and modeling of concrete system requirements are activities that can be performed interactively. Also, non-functional requirements and constraints should be gathered or refined from the business needs discovered previously. Discovering what a system should do to satisfy business needs is usually done using prototypes, use scenarios, user histories analysis, interviews, etc.

item.title: 4. Model Concrete System Requirements
item.description:
Concrete system requirements specify functions or actions that a system must implement or a performance condition a system must achieve.
SysML is a standard that provides modeling constructs to represent text-based requirements and relate them to other modeling elements in detail system design. The requirements can be depicted in a graphical, tabular, or tree structure format. A requirement can also appear on other diagrams to show its relationship to other modeling elements. A detailed explanation of SysML can be found in its official webpage (http://www.omg.org/spec/SysML/).

subitem.label: If you applied the SysML14 profile to your model in the step 2. Model Business Needs. You can skip the next three sub-steps.
Click on the root element which is a model package in the Model Explorer
Select Apply Registered Profile > OK in the in the Property view
Select SysML14 > Select all > Finish
Configure SysML requirements preference settings: Right click on the model package > Papyrus for Requirements - Preference Settings
Create a SysML Requirements diagram and tables by right clicking your model in the model explorer
New Diagram > SysML14 Requirement Diagram or New Table > SysML14 Requirement Tree Table

item.title: 5. Relate Business Needs to Concrete Systems Requirements
item.description:
The business needs must be connected to concrete system requirements so we can guarantee traceability between technical and business views.
To create a traceability matrix between elements belonging to models written using the BMM and SysML languages you have to follow the next sub-steps:
(Remember that requirement engineering is an iterative process and if I you need more information, you can go the previous steps to elicit, model and relate business needs and concrete systems requirements)

subitem.label: Right click on a package that contains the requirements that you want to trace
Select New table > SysML14 Requirements - Papyrus for Requirements TraceTo Matrix
Right click on a package that contains the requirements that you want to trace
Enter the name for the new table and finish.

item.title: 6. Verify and Validate Requirements
item.description: It is necessary to validate that the requirements really define the system that the customer wants and that the models pass some verification rules. We provide automated support for checking requirements against a predefined set of rules.

subitem.label: Right click on a package or model that contains the requirements that you want to validate
Select SysML14 Requirements - Validation > Select constraints and validate model
Check all the constraints to evaluate in the category Papyrus for Requirements > Apply > OK
See the warnings about potential problems in the diagram, model, property and table views.

item.title: 7. Trace Requirements to Design and Tests Models
item.description:
Management of requirements is heavily supported by requirements traceability. This is crucial for the maintenance and evolution of the requirements models.
We already use a trace matrix to link business needs to concrete system requirements. Now, we will add more relationships as defined by the SysML standard using matrices. For example, we have the matrices:
DerivedFrom (connects technology independent requirements to more technology-specific requirements),
RefinedBy (connects requirements to use cases or activity diagrams that give more information about them),
SatisfiedBy (connects requirements to the design artefacts that implement them),
TracedTo (connects requirements to documentation and to business needs) and
VarifiedBy (connects requirements to test cases which can be modeled using activity diagrams or state machines).
Follow the next steps to create traceability matrices:

subitem.label: Right click on a package that contains the requirements that you want to trace
Select New table > SysML14 Requirements - Papyrus for Requirements * Matrix
Enter the name for the new table and finish.
Check the intersection between the requirement (column) and other elements (rows).

item.title: 8. Calculate Metrics
item.description: Management, specification and validation activities are supported by quantitative information usually referred to as metrics. This information can be used to measure the advancement of the requirements engineering activity. Follow the next steps to calculate the values of predefined metrics, such as number of requirements, number of (un)satisfied requirements, number of (un)verified requirements, etc.:

subitem.label: Right click on a package that contains the requirements that you want to analyse
Select Papyrus Metrics > Get Measure Values
See the results in the Metrics view
